|       [Jmol](https://jmol.sourceforge.net/) is a free, open-source program for visualizing and manipulating three-dimensional molecular structures. Distributed under the* GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL)*, Jmol offers a variety of functionalities, including:

*    Diverse color rendering options
*    Molecular rotation and translation
*    Zoom functionality
*    Distance and angle calculations
*    Visualization of structures and surfaces
*    Molecular optimization routines
*    Animation capabilities

## Jmol: Multi-Platform Accessibility

|       Jmol is a multi-platform program, meaning it can run on various operating systems like Windows, Mac OS, and Linux. It can be installed traditionally or used as an *applet*, a web-based application that does not require local installation. When installed, Jmol can access files from your hard drive or removable media (USB drives).

![](jsmol.png){width=20%}

## Online Learning Resources with JSmol

|       The provided links offer online learning materials for studying biomolecules using *JSmol*, a web-based version of Jmol. These resources, adapted from the ebook [Bioquímica Estrutural Guiada Por Jmol](.\BioqEstrutJmol.pdf) (Editora Unifal-MG, 2019, *in Portuguese*), do not require local software installation. The content focuses on facilitating the independent learning of key biomolecular structures through interactive visualization with JSmol.

|       The author also provides downloadable resources related to Jmol and Biochemistry. These include:

*    The ebook [Bioquímica Estrutural Guiada Por Jmol](.\BioqEstrutJmol.pdf)
*    Renderable 3D models from the ebook: these models can be accessed individually [by chapter](.\figBook\figuras.html) or downloaded as a [single compressed file](.\figBook\figBook.zip). These models can be viewed statically with an image viewer (2D model), or dynamically (3D rendering), with *Jmol.*

## Other Molecular Visualization Software:

|       Several other programs offer functionalities similar to Jmol, including standalone software for desktop computers, mobile applications (Android, iPhone), and online platforms. A simple web search can help you find programs like:

*[Pymol](https://pymol.org/2/), *[Maestro](https://www.schrodinger.com/products/maestro), *[iMolView](https://www.molsoft.com/iMolview.html), *[VMD](https://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Development/Download/download.cgi?PackageName=VMD), *[UCSF Chimera](https://www.cgl.ucsf.edu/chimera/) *[Vesta](https://jp-minerals.org/vesta/en/), and *[QuteMol](https://qutemol.sourceforge.net/), among several.
